Authors: Yu Ping Liang, Chao jung Wu, Hui Wen Tsai, Hui Fang Ni
Title:
Identification and pathogenicity of Lasiodiplodia species
associated with avocado branch canker in Taiwan
Keywords:
Avocado, Branch canker, Lasiodiplodia theobromae,
Lasiodiplodia pseudotheobromae, Taiwan
Abstract:
Avocado branch canker disease has been reported in many
avocado-growing countries, and is associated with several species in the
Botryosphaeriaceae family. In Taiwan, the disease is widely distributed
in the main avocado-producing regions. Therefore, the aims of this study
were to identify and characterize the pathogens associated with avocado
branch canker in Taiwan, and evaluate their pathogenicity. Thirteen
fungal isolates were obtained from necrotic avocado woody tissues from
seven orchards located in different regions of Taiwan. Based on
morphology and phylogenetic analyses of the internal transcribed spacer
sequence and partial sequences of the translation elongation factor 1-α
and beta-tubulin genes, the isolates were identified as either
Lasiodiplodia theobromae or Lasiodiplodia pseudotheobromae. In addition,
species-specific primers were developed for rapid identification of
these two species. The optimal temperature for mycelial growth for both
species was around 30°C. Pathogenicity tests showed that both species
were pathogenic to avocado, causing a whitish exudate at the inoculation
site and necrosis on the stem and black lesions on the fruit. The
information about the pathogens of avocado branch canker in Taiwan
obtained in this study will be useful for future research on
establishing effective disease management strategies in avocado. To our
knowledge, this is the first report characterizing avocado branch canker
in Taiwan.
